Globally Distributed Training Setting

We train a billion parameter scale model across three countries.

Due to DiLoCo’s reduction in communication time, the all-reduce bottleneck only took up 6.9% of the training time, minimally impacting the overall training speed. https://t.co/khRumKtE0p https://t.co/gNmpdHpR00

Scaling DiLoCo to Billion Parameter Models

The original DiLoCo work only experimented with model sizes of up to 400 million parameters. We scale the method to a 1.1 billion parameter model.

While we demonstrate that DiLoCo works at the billion-parameter scale, we believe… https://t.co/klkVLJ1IyL https://t.co/ZILrNh46kp

We replicate the main experiment results and show that DiLoCo with 8 replicas significantly outperforms the baseline without any replicas and matches the performance of a stronger baseline with the same compute budget, despite 500x lower communication. https://t.co/ULdfVvDlFb

It took me nearly 2 years to grasp the difference between doing something in software versus in hardware.

In my opinion, NYC is the only city that solved this problem in America. The subway takes no space above ground and it renders cars nearly useless.

I was really hoping the hyperloop would work out @elonmusk

Adding stores where there are now roads  and parking is a clear incentive, combined with the rise of self driving taxis. Converting swaths of outdoor parking to vertical parking structures is another almost “free lunch.”

I honestly don’t know what a full solution would look like without completely uprooting our infrastructure, but there have to be economic incentives for all sides involved. Solutions like “drive less” won’t do the trick at a large enough scale.

What can we do about this? Guilt tripping drivers isn’t the answer. Ads like this from BART look at the problem from a high level, using statistics to paint YOU as the bad guy. The reality is, each of those drivers have a unique set of circumstances that dictate their choices. https://t.co/eI1l5tQbmS

This makes it so no one has to travel more than a half mile for daily errands, hence more walking and less driving. Contrasting that with my parents driving 3 miles for groceries in a relatively nice Bay Area neighborhood, it’s easy to see why we have this problem.

It’s not uncommon to see shops stacked on top of each other, too.

Notice I’m saying “shops” instead of “stores.” There aren’t many Targets in India, but there are hundreds of street vendors and small merchant shops scattered throughout urban areas.

This culture is also shaped by the way cities are organized in India. The sheer size of the population increases density of housing and shops, squeezing out space for roads.

They also utilize the vertical axis very well. Most families live in apartments with underground parking.

To my knowledge, most people in India ride motorcycles and scooters when running errands, and take auto rickshaws or Ubers when going longer distances.

The culture encourages maximal utilization of the available resources.

What did these countries do that America couldn’t? The obvious answer is good public transit; Sydney was ranked 14th out of 60 cities for best public transportation. But NYC is 13th, SF is 16th, and LA isn’t last for some reason. Clearly there are more factors at play.
Australia isn’t the only place you can find points of interest without acres of wasted space. Here’s Wankhede stadium in India: https://t.co/xQ2al2lhbj

Is it just America that’s built this way? This TikTok that went viral a few weeks ago suggests that it might be true. Check out the glaring lack of parking at the MCG compared to these stadiums in Kansas City. https://t.co/LHS1cpmAgf

SF & Berkeley suck for all kinds of reasons, but at least they’re somewhat navigable by public transit.

Suburban areas (e.g. Dublin) are covered in urban sprawl to the point that taking a walk almost feels psychotic.

It’s insane how we give up so much space in our cities to moving and storing cars.

A rant, perhaps? 🧵
I have nearly been robbed/attacked/kidnapped at Berkeley twice in the past month. Self-defense is no longer optional.
Truth is, involving yourself in every issue that comes your way after learning <10% of the whole picture probably isn’t the best for your mental health or anyone else’s.

Berkeley has always been the hub of progressive thought, which arguably brought us more tech innovation than any other city in America.

The byproduct - immense pressure to become engrossed in political issues, radicalizing people on all sides. https://t.co/NrZ6lyj0hO

But please leave the damn 40 lb basmati rice bags in Costco alone, they aren’t going anywhere.

India specifically banned exports of non-basmati rice, so we still have enough basmati to sustain everyone in America, not to mention local-grown rice and imports from other countries like China.

In another scenario the ultimate winner could be open source AGIs as they will be equally capable, more flexible and accessible and probably cheaper to run.
This could lead to a scenario where all major AGI-providing companies will win and yet lose at the same time as there will be no monopoly!
If every AGI, by definition, has the capability to self-improve then theoretically they could all reach a similar level of performance!

If you’re driving too fast you pretty much don’t need to check your blind spot for other cars when maneuvering left or right. Same thing with startups that move fast, they don’t need to worry about their competition too much in every turn!
Another possibility is that a new paradigm far superior to our current one of leveraging LLMs and Assistants will emerge leading us directly to AGI

But if we figure out how to build reliable Assistants and make them communicate effectively, we'll have what appears to be AGI to the end user. And perhaps, with the data collected from these Assistants in the wild, someday we'll be able to integrate them into one cohesive AGI

There are so many things to figure out for such an ecosystem to work, e.g. authentication and authorization between Assistants, ensuring repeatability so that Assistants complete the same task in the same way, etc
For example, an Assistant might build another Assistant to sync a user's Robinhood data, enabling it to perform analytics and another Assistant to store and query the user's preferences

Soon, these Assistants will be able to communicate with each other to perform more complex tasks. More interestingly, they'll be able to create other Assistants for collaboration to complete specific jobs

Each OpenAI Assistant is practically a micro-service: a tiny backend with access to data and other APIs

The fascinating aspect of the Assistants is that they may reveal a roadmap to AGI…

TLDR: A lot to look forward to in the software & algorithms world if the LK-99 superconductor comes to fruition, specifically because of the prospect of increasing clock frequencies. (19/19)

So best of all, as we continue towards an increasingly parallel world involving multicore processors and GPUs, all the processors/cores in these different chips get much faster with the increase in clock speed! (18/x)
And also, while this tweet thread may come across as "clock frq increases >> # of processor increases," the truth is, they are both complementary and key to future computing advances. (17/x)

Algorithms that have not undergone significant speedups since the mid-2000's (at least, not as large as the speedups in parallelizable algorithms), such as the stable matching algorithm, can truly start getting much faster again. (16/x)
Now, we're back to increasing clock frq (potentially by orders of magnitude!), and creating speedups in all algorithms, parallelizable or not, *and* without any overhead costs. (15/x)

With room-temperature supercomputers, we can mitigate the overheating caused by increasing clock frq, because they are far more efficient than semiconductors like silicon, and dissipate much less heat that needs to be cooled. (14/x)
So, how do room-temperature superconductors play into this? (13/x)

Additionally, even for algos that *are* parallelizable, doubling # of processors never leads to 2x performance, due to overhead costs (the computational cost of breaking down a program into separate pieces on different processors + the cost of combining all the results). (12/x)

Thus, point-blank, a 2x increase in clock frq is better than doubling the number of processors from a pure software performance standpoint, because all algorithms benefit from increases in frq, whereas only parallelizable algorithms benefit from more processors. (11/x)

However, other algorithms, especially those relying on a series of sequential steps like the stable matching algorithm, hardly benefit from parallelization. It is hard to turn these algorithms into independent computations that can run in parallel on different processors. (10/x) https://t.co/EviRQSrZ6u

Some algorithms can easily be parallelized, such as matrix multiplication. For example, when you parallelize matrix multiplication, different processors compute different values in the resulting matrix. (9/x)

Instead, you need to be creative, and do things unconventionally. 

The blue ocean strategy always wins.

If you want to succeed, often working ‘harder’ is not the solution. 

Hard work is necessary to succeed, but it is not what separates success from failure.

The problem with chasing competition is that you end up operating in relatively efficient markets. 

You ‘alpha’ will be smaller in these free markets. 

Instead, you want to pursue markets with large inefficiencies, where you have a significant edge.

After all, the ‘9-5’ is only a hundred years old. 

Most ‘rules’ and not actually ‘rules’.

But this blue ocean strategy is less commonly applied to other areas of life. 

Applying for jobs, looking for spouses, designing a career. 

Social defaults are rampant in a world stifled by timidity.

AirBnb was stupid because people wouldn’t feel comfortable letting random strangers into their car. 

Uber was ‘just a taxi company’.

Something I believe is that the best opportunities won’t look like opportunities at all. 

After all, if they were so obvious, then everybody would be pursuing them. 

This is commonly accepted in the world of startup investing.

But in the process of competing, we also become highly mimetic. 

We inherit our desires from those around us. 

After all, in order to ‘compete’, we must be playing the same game as somebody else.

When you enter primary school, there are awards to the student who is most academic. 

The student with the highest exam score is deemed the ‘smartest’.

Conclusion — There's a DIRE need for flexible, plug and play loyalty tools that can accommodate the dynamic nature of current customer engagement / community experience. If you want your loyalty program to be scalable, interactive and build a partner program, DM me for the guide!

When designing a new program keep in mind that Omni-channel interaction, Reward Redemption via partner programs and Exclusive Access/Experiences where Customers can showcase their status were voted as the top benefits.

Building a Reward Partner program is more critical then ever. Yet, existing programs often offer only 3-6 fixed benefits, and only at sales point. 1 in 3 customers churn after redeeming all the fixed benefits. And, Brands see existing tools as sunk cost...

Why are loyalty programs not targeting the top 10%?
With more choices than ever, today’s customers demand more… 80% customers stated they will stay in a brand if their reward has utility – either frequency of usage or other redemption areas. So what should you do as a brand? 🤔

~80% of a brand’s revenue typically comes from just 10% of its customer base. Yet, 2/3 brands still spend $$$ on ads and are seeing 2x more costs in acquisition with lower retention (customer acquisition costs are 60% higher than before!)
So we dug deeper...

Over the past 2 years, we have talked to 300+ brands (10440+ minutes spent) on their brand loyalty and retention needs so you didn’t have to. Here’s what we found that you NEED to know if you are managing a brand…
One of the largest markets with little innovation.. how did we sleep on this for decades?

It surprises me every day ( and excites me) that existing loyalty providers for enterprise usually look for $200k upfront costs and "intentionally" do not build a CRM or analytics tool for customers so that they need the provider again whenever the program needs a change...

Traditional providers stifle program growth and flexibility, forcing brands to rely heavily on agencies for even minor changes –   due to the absence of integrations and composable components or rewards by existing providers.

Did you know...Most loyalty Programs often offer only 3-6 fixed benefits, and only at sales points.  

With the Rise of CAC, customers are demanding more... yet loyalty benefits are only changeable with significant engineering intervention within current systems.

Now, even tho its clear that it saves time by parking far...

We’ll still be looking for a spot close to the store entrance cuz that’s what the gf wants lol.

Results:
Close Spot Total Time Over 6 Months: 104 minutes.
Far Spot Total Time Over 6 Months (with adjusted walk time): 96 minutes. https://t.co/LkRDQ8Ukh0

Far Spot Strategy:
Each Trip: 0 minutes finding + 4 minutes walking = 4 minutes per trip.
Total for 24 trips: 4 min per trip×24 trips=96 min. https://t.co/9z5IBBJTHY

Data Analysis:
Close Spot Strategy:
- Normal Trips (2 out of 3): 1 minute finding + 2 minutes walking = 3 minutes per trip.
- Adjusted Trip (1 out of 3): 5 minutes finding + 2 minutes walking = 7 minutes for this trip.
Every 3 trips: 6 min for 2 trips + 7 min for 1 trip=13 min
-… https://t.co/XK6FoUYyMJ

Far Spot Strategy:
No time spent finding a spot.
2 minutes walk each way (4 minutes walking total). https://t.co/6BmQLNp4FO

Close Spot Strategy:

Normal condition: 1 minute to find a spot, 1 minute walk each way (2 minutes walking total).

Sometimes it takes a while to find a spot. So, for every 2-3 trips: 5 minutes to find a spot due to increased competition, 1 minute walk each way. https://t.co/P2eceMJLfm

Assumptions
(I actually timed these assumptions)
- Grocery Shopping Frequency: 24 trips over 6 months.
-  2 Strategies: Close Spot Strategy and Far Spot Strategy https://t.co/s7HUnfNZ0S

The EU aims to finalize the AI ACT by the end of the year. This legislation could set a precedent for AI regulation worldwide, balancing the benefits of AI with the need to protect individual rights and freedoms.

The tech industry's reactions to the proposed EU legislation on AI use are mixed. Some call for legislation, others criticize it as too prescriptive and potentially hindering innovation. The final shape of the legislation is currently under discussion. https://t.co/c7J9DzMWWy
Technologies like Chat GPT have influenced discussions around the legislation, with lawmakers considering adding new elements to prevent the creation of illegal content.

The creation of illegal content by AI is also a concern. The AI ACT aims to prevent this by requiring companies to publish summaries of copyrighted data used to train AI models, ensuring the output doesn't infringe on copyright laws. https://t.co/AkzaI2jMmr

Predictive policing is another high-risk application. It involves using AI to predict potential criminal activity based on data like criminal histories and real-time biometric surveillance.

https://t.co/gUyghLtqeA

One high-risk application is the use of facial recognition tools. While useful, they can infringe on privacy rights if not properly regulated. The AI ACT aims to put guardrails around such applications to ensure ethical use. https://t.co/wEr5vaeUl1

The EU Parliament is pushing forward the AI ACT. 

The goal? To establish guidelines around the development and use of AI, particularly for high-risk applications.

Our results suggest a greater semantic alignment between the image and text modalities than previously thought, and they demonstrate how to use interpretability tooling to repair and enhance model capabilities. 🚀🚀

We also use our confidence scores to precisely detect where objects are in an image with LLaVA, which spatially maps image tokens with specific image patches, and achieve near-SOTA zero-shot segmentation performance. https://t.co/1kS60RRft4

We discover that subtracting object text embeddings (e.g. “dog”) from image representations effectively erases those objects from image captions. 

Applying this method, we erase hallucinations with low confidence scores and reduce hallucinations by ~25% for two VLMs. https://t.co/GBnJe6OiC3

We project the internal representations of image tokens to the LLM’s language vocabulary and create a confidence score based on output probabilities for text tokens. 

We find that real objects have much higher confidence scores than random objects and hallucinations! https://t.co/CKICBdQM5Q

Language models normally can’t “see”. VLMs work by turning images into ‘tokens’ fed into a LLM using a frozen encoder (CLIP) and mapping layer.

But given the minimal end-to-end training between the vision encoder and LLM, what information do these image tokens capture? https://t.co/MGU25d5yyz

🔥 Paper Drop 🔥

What can we understand by peering inside vision-language models (VLMs) like LLaVA?

We show that image representations inside VLMs can be directly interpreted and edited in the language space, and we apply our findings to mitigate hallucinations! https://t.co/PGNLYhKkhv
I think it makes sense to have intuition guide us, but my hope is that moral philosophers will have a clearer statement of axiomatic, fundamental values they believe in.

From Scheffler's "What is Egalitarianism?":

A: Inequalities are unjust if they're due to unchosen circumstances.

S: Suppose there is a naturally talented swimmer. This inequality of talent is unjust by A, which contradicts our "prevailing political morality"  -> A is wrong. https://t.co/WYTVV4VqLQ

One common objection to argument A is to say that statement S logically follows from A, and S contradicts A somehow. This is a logically sound method of objecting. But when the reason S contradicts A is purely because S is "absurd" or "strikes us as wrong", it seems arbitrary.
Rather than arguing for what should be right, moral philosophy becomes an attempt to articulate our "intuition" for what is right, which is often contradictory and vulnerable to personal ideologies.

Moral philosophy heavily relies on "intuition" to argue for claims and make judgments. There tends to not be a set of logical axioms one can reduce an argument to; rather, it just "feels" or "sounds" right.

Engineering fulfillment comes when it’s uncertain whether your designed system will work, and it actually does work. The more uncertainty (ex. from expansive scope, # edge cases), the more personally fulfilling. The inverse is true too.

The challenge with making education personalized is that a magical part of school is actually learning together. 

There's something great about working with classmates on the same problems, discussing thoughts about the same readings, and progressing as a whole, not just as one.

In software, you sit in a chair coding or at a whiteboard with colleagues brainstorming; the real world is obscured from you. It's not an easy career, but you don't have to deal with the *burden* of something real, direct, and tangible.

Software is the type of career that abstracts away the messiness of ordinary life.

It's the direct opposite of a career like neurosurgery, where you must overcome any decision-making paralysis and make judgment calls with real, undeniable consequences.

The issue with interpretability research is that it's hard to do and even harder to know if you've succeeded.
IMO interpretability is an under-rated field in ML. If we can understand what exactly makes transformers work so well, we can build something better much faster.

I’m not saying that performance improvements specific to transformers will become irrelevant because they're clearly very applicable alr, but it also seems inevitable that something better will replace the transformer, in which case we’ll need to repeat this optimization cycle.

Is LLM systems research premature optimization? I'm seeing work (ex. vLLM) that fiddles with the transformer architecture to speed up training, inference, etc. But despite their strengths, transformers still have a lot of weaknesses (ex. with reasoning).

lol one of the most memorable teachers https://t.co/i1Roxm5Hcr

3. There exists a WIDE spectrum of attitudes toward tech. Many teachers are frustrated with tech because they're constantly switching to new platforms. Edtech companies also don't take their feedback seriously enough. Any product should emphasize ease-of-use and integration.
Some teachers derive meaning from the grading process but generally want less of it, particularly history teachers (who have tons of content to go through).

2. Teachers are overloaded with grading. They consistently named grading among their most time-consuming tasks / biggest headaches.
Increasing class sizes + staff shortages = more to grade with less time
At the same time, teachers are generally concerned about cheating with ChatGPT, creating a push to have students work on pen-and-paper in classes

1. Assignments are going digital. Lot to do with the pandemic - schools invested heavily in Chromebooks, students developed habits for working digitally (ex. getting feedback for essay on Google doc, not on hard copy), teachers relied on sites like Google Classroom

this ofc is to be paired with communications regulations placed on 'gateways' or 'touch points' in the DeFi transaction flow (ex. RPC NaaS)

in my developing opinion, regulation for genuine DeFi protocols should focus on (1) industry-wide standards, (2) implementation of cybersecurity standards, (3) information sharing and analysis centers, (4) automation on risk indicators and similar risk mitigation tools

(list continued)
- introducing intermediaries into DeFi to guarantee stricter regulatory guardrails = re-introducing switchboard operators for telephone calls that verify caller identities... it just doesn't make sense

boiled down to the fundamentals:
- don't try to fix what is (not completely) broken: for any on-chain CeFi actor (any centralized party that can exercise centralized control) that behaves *exactly* like a 'financial institution', keep the same ol' BSA regulations

When reading about blockchain base layer neutrality, its fascinating to see the deep-rooted connections between the blockchain revolution and preceding Internet revolutions, as I feel like we view crypto in its own bubble (its rather a result of other tech evolutions)

Its true that some protocols recreate existing services in a decentralized way, but it rubs off the wrong way when applied to regulatory policies because we need fundamentally different guardrails between a intermediary-dependent and an intermediary-free financial system

just a few thoughts to share below abt DeFi <> on-chain CeFi <> regulation during some of my readings 🧵

feel free to comment your thoughts and/or questions, or reach out with any opinions or recs for further readings

5/ Appropriate Safeguards

⛔ Privacy-preserving KYC/AML mechanisms

🧠 Privacy standards for institutional clients to protect the financial IP

👨‍💻 Cybersecurity protections

🗳️ Mature governance models with appropriate liability recourse for investors

4/ Infrastructure Design

🛑 Permissioned DLT environments as security and scalability take precedence over decentralization

🔐 Security token standards help store mission-critical information about the asset being represented while also allowing for fractionalization

3/ Why hasn’t everything been tokenized yet?

🛠️ There doesn’t exist an industry-standard token or environment design

🤷‍♂️  Regulatory uncertainty is a major roadblock

📈 There's gotta be an expressed need for institutional players and traditional assets to migrate on-chain

1/ Institutional DeFi can be broken down into 3 components:

1️⃣ Traditional Asset Tokenization

2️⃣ Infrastructure Design

3️⃣ Appropriate Safeguards

Fast-forward to now, the journey has come full circle. My startup, @TunnelHQ, now has the backing of @apartovi and @neo. It's absolutely mind-boggling that one of the individuals who had a part in making me a programmer is now supporting us through our startup journey. (12/12)
This venture was my inaugural foray into the world of business. The interplay of coding and commerce was addictive. And I haven’t stopped since. (11/12)
I scaled my operation. Four months later, I operated 5 Android phones and a tablet, all running my custom-made program, and was making a million coins every week. (10/12)

Then came the revelation: I could convert these virtual coins to real money. Selling my first million coins brought me $300. The realization that I could monetize my coding skills was exhilarating. (9/12)
Victory was swift. In a week, I not only surpassed my friends in the game but also accumulated the most coins. (8/12)
Harnessing my newfound programming skills, I programmed an Android phone to scour the marketplace 24/7. It would snap up these deals and resell the players for a profit. (7/12)
In Madden Mobile, there were fleeting moments when high-value players were sold cheaply on the marketplace due to user error. These deals vanished in seconds, making them hard to catch. (6/12)

During that summer, my friends were completely absorbed in Madden Mobile, an iPhone football game where you accumulate coins to buy players and build your own team. Naturally, my competitive nature drove me to strive for the highest number of coins and the strongest squad. (5/12)
Throughout the entire vacation, I became fixated on completing the catalog. I spent the entire day sitting in a beach chair, tirelessly working on it until I finally finished. (4/12)
I went to one session, and then my family was going on a February break vacation. I pleaded with my parents to bring the laptop along so that I could continue coding. (3/12)

Honestly, this might end up being a completely separate major, because there is definitely value in a traditional computer science education. However, in the current cohort of CS students, most of them will never use what they learn. (7/7)

I'm not suggesting that we replace the entire curriculum. However, supplementing it could prove to be beneficial. This way, we might actually apply what we learn, instead of cramming from LeetCode and relearning data structures just a week before job interviews. (6/7)

Instead of every core course being on arcane languages or the nth implementation of some sorting algorithm, how about requiring in-depth courses on TypeScript, modern cloud infrastructures, OSS, or even CSS? (5/7)
We need a more realistic computer science education, that still focuses some on the fundamentals, but with an emphasis on more practical uses. (4/7)

These are definitely useful and interesting skills for some. But for a lot of us, they're not going to be relevant to our everyday work. From what I saw, the majority of my classmates would tune out or scrape by, because they knew they'd never use this stuff. (3/7)
Last semester, I sat through a "Principles of Software" class that focused almost 2 months on writing Java-specific unit tests. And I remember thinking, is this really the best use of my time? (2/7)

It's time to revisit the computer science curriculum. There are definitely some people who enjoy the fundamentals, grind leetcode, and do advertisement optimization at a FANG company, but that isn’t everyone going into the major anymore. (1/7)

Roommates have helped each other with everything from product feedback to hiring decisions, fundraising, general strategy advice, etc.

We have each others backs. We all care about winning. And we've fostered a community that takes care of each other.

The only way to learn those skills is to 1) fail a bunch and 2) learn from other people.

Even if you learn from other people you will fail a ton, so having a group of other young people who are also failing and have your back is invaluable

For any young person who wants to build a really successful company, the roadblocks in front of you are insane.

You will know nothing about building great products, marketing and selling them, hiring great people, fundraising, nor any other important skills.

5. Link-Building Sprint
- Make a list of your competitors
- Extract their backlinks to a Google Doc
- Remove low-quality & irrelevant links
- Categorize the posts
- For each category, create a custom outreach email
- Write something unique, without AI
- Start blasting emails!

3. Content Sprint
- Start publishing content. It's a game of volume
- Pick out a category. Filter by ascending difficulty. Publish all articles for that category ASAP
- Interlink all similar articles together
- Move on to a different category, repeat

2. Keyword Research
- Identify keywords
- Run them through the SEMrush keyword tool
- Set keyword difficulty. Extract relevant ones
- Do this for all keywords
- Copy-paste keywords to an AI tool to generate more ideas
- Keep going until you’ve exhausted all keywords

1. Content Audit

@shelbygrossman @sbradshaww In our paper, we study posts were identified by the Election Integrity Partnership (a coalition of civil society groups) and sent to the relevant platforms where employees confirmed receipt, giving us a robust view into platforms' moderation decisions.

@shelbygrossman @sbradshaww As a result, it's hard to collect a robust, representative dataset of content to analyze.

So how can we reliably study enforcement patterns and assess platform consistency?

@shelbygrossman @sbradshaww Platforms' moderation decisions are typically a black box to outside researchers: It's challenging to determine whether platforms' content moderators assessed a particular piece of content, and moderation decisions typically aren't accessible through APIs.

@shelbygrossman @sbradshaww Platforms' content moderation decisions play a large role in mediating online discourse, especially during elections. Were social media platforms consistent in how they labeled content in the run-up to the 2020 election?

What content did platforms label as misleading in the run up to the 2020 election? And were platforms consistent in their labeling decisions?

Separation of concerns in managing an early-stage startup codebase is massively underrated.

@TarunAmasa Together, we’re working on https://t.co/2hCj5H8gpm, which aligns with both of these two longer-term moats. We’re starting with the financial markets, where 1. Financial analysis workflows are antiquated but necessarily complex, and 2. Data is scattered and SNR low. Stay tuned!

To add, these are purely the moats. Sure, enterprise value creation from AI can come from places currently unimaginable. But longer term, don’t think any wrapper co can survive without verticalizing into one of these 2. 

Cc my cofounder, @TarunAmasa, who shares this thesis :)

My personal thesis is that startup value creation moats in AI for X only come in two forms:

1. Deep integration into complex workflows
2. Data aggregation across traditionally hard-to-access places

Existing co’s w/ distribution can and will eat everything “easier” than this.

Thinking about taking a leave of absence from school to work on my edtech startup, build some LLM projects, and read/write more. 

Where should I live to make the most of it?
(Choices in order of my current preferences)

Cultivate the things in your life that draw your presence. And make an active effort not to get distracted by the things that pull you away. I hope to live an intentionally present life, and I hope you do too :)
(🧵7/7)

The principle of being present being correlated with being happier has made me realize I need to better cull what distracts from being present and build in what *forces* me to be present. 
Working out, reading, playing board games, etc force me to be there, so I enjoy them.
(6/7)

"Deep leisure", as I call it, where you are fully present in even the mundane things you do, can allow you to trick your brain into enjoying the everyday things too. I don't enjoy hiking when I'm on my phone but I love it when I'm present in nature/enjoying a conversation.
(5/7)

A funny thing I've noticed is that people capable of deep work often are restless in leisure. 

At the dining hall, I see smart and presumably busy people interrupt conversations over lunch with friends to respond to an urgent text or even just scroll on Instagram. 
(🧵4/7)

But even apart from work, I've found that the number one detractor from my happiness in relaxation is when I feel the urge to check my phone's notifications. It introduces opportunity cost (shoot,  is there something better to be doing?) when there previously was none.
(🧵3/7)

One of my happiest friends told me that their secret sauce was in trying to be present in everything they did, no matter how much they didn't want to do it. 

I realized that even when I don't want to work, getting locked-in always makes it fulfilling/enjoyable in the end.
(2/7)

A super simple life hack a friend taught me:

Being present == being happier.

It's a simple idea, yet it explains so much. Let me explain the power of being fully locked-in and enjoying the moment, from work to leisure:

(🧵1/7)

1) O’Grady, Patricia F. Thales of Miletus: The Beginnings of Western Science and Philosophy. Ashgate, 2002.

2) Aristotle, and Carnes Lord. Aristotle’s Politics. Second edition, The University of Chicago Press, 2013.

6/ According to Aristotle, Thales only became wealthy to prove that his knowledge could be practical. For Thales, it wasn't even about the money -- he just wanted a bag to prove to people he could be rich.

5/ When the bumper crop arrived, Thales controlled the entire olive oil market. With demand high and no competition, he rented out the presses at a premium, generating substantial profits – creating a Thiel-esque monopoly.

4/ Using his knowledge, Thales predicted a bountiful olive harvest. He then secured funding to place deposits on all the olive presses in Miletus and Chios during the off-season, effectively creating a monopoly on olive oil production.

3/ Thales diligently studied weather patterns using the resources available to him. He used tools like the gnomon (primitive sundial) to measure the length of shadows and determine the solstices and equinoxes. Thales also observed the stars, tracked seasons, and analyzed climate… https://t.co/EQP50s9K8V
2/ Thales was often mocked by his peers for his poverty. He was ridiculed for being a theoretician, incapable of practical matters. However, Thales was determined to prove his peers wrong.

1/ Born in the 6th century BCE, Thales was a Greek polymath who contributed greatly to math and science. He accurately predicted a solar eclipse and derived the eponymous Thales's Theorem. Yet, despite his genius, Thales was a broke boy.

4. Most importantly, our team has been learning a lot and getting more comfortable developing on Solana, honing skills many of us had only scratched the surface with when starting this project just several weeks ago.

Anyway, back to building 💪💪

2. Started integrating native tests in Rust, as well as Rust client code that will form the foundation for in-house crank script(s).
3. Close to completing implementation of our on-chain registry for renewal/expiration.

Hello hello! The last two weeks we've been doing some heavy lifting:

1. Redesigned initialize + renew instr flow for better devX and security, implementing soon. Finishing up the withdraw instr. Will update docs to reflect technical updates once completed.

Hey everyone! Exciting stuff is currently in the works: final instructions, Rust API, JS/TS API, and a v2 written in @anchorlang. More details to come soon.

And it's all built by a team of devs from @ILL_Blockchain who were looking for something to build for #riptidehackathon. Stay tuned for more progress!

We’re especially excited to be building Buoyant because we’re making subscriptions tradable. Sick of Netflix after 20 days? Sell it to someone looking for a 10-day trial for cheaper. This makes it possible for subs to be a new derivative-like asset tradable on open markets.
Recurring payments are a powerful primitive that haven’t really surfaced in crypto quite yet, however low-cost blockchains like @solana are finally making it practical.

Regulation in AI development and usage sets guidelines  to prevent misuse of the technology, protect individuals' rights, and address biases. 

However excessive restrictive regulation may hinder & slow down innovation, or even burden some business.

What is your stance?

(6/6)

GPAI developers are mainly subject to obligations related to high-risk systems, such as conformity assessments, risk management, testing, and data governance.

Foundation model developers face stricter requirements, including extensive analysis, testing, and vetting. 

(5/6)

A risk-based approach is adopted, categorizing AI systems into categories:

- minimal risk (no restriction)
- limited risk (Transparency needed)
- high-risk (requires compliance)
- unacceptable (prohibited)

Each category is then associated obligations and requirements.

(4/6)

The Act defines AI systems, including artificial intelligence models and GPAI. 

The Act promotes a human-centric approach and prohibits certain practices, like developing biometric systems for specific situations and using emotion recognition software in law enforcement.

(3/6)

The European Internal Market & Consumer Protection and the Civil Liberties, Justice, & Home Affairs announced their work towards AI.

This EU AI Act aims to regulate AI practices, ensure trustworthy development, and establish obligations and requirements for AI systems. 

(2/6)

Should there be regulations on AI?
Europeans think yes.

Here is what you need to know about the world’s first-ever legislation on artificial intelligence!

Lastly,  
-Learn to Love. Love the small things about your day. Love the fact that your friend lives only 3 minutes.  Love the fact that you will have struggles.  

 & If you're lucky - love your best friend
-Learn courage. The courage to ask a friend to grab dinner, to say f*it, and take a trip. To say f* it I am going to take the hardest class on campus.

-Learn how Not to fail. You will inevitably fail, but try to learn from the people around you on what to do, and what NOT to do. 

There will be plenty of people that can provide you with examples both.
-Learn the value of everything. We know the value of bread and Airpods. But now is your time to learn the value of friendships, knowledge, time, activities, hardships, and opportunities.

-Learn that the ONLY thing that can change you and your you, is your mind. Your mindset. 

And what affects that? What you input into your brain. So, input whatever you want your output to be.

-Learn how to think. (Different points of view). Frameworks on your approach to something. 

-Learn to be open-minded, and to be firm on your morals at the same time. 

I think you see the common theme here is to learn the intangibles//

-Learn about the people around you - not just your friends: your classmates, your professors - they are incredible. 

-Take advantage of opportunities. I promise you there are so many that you are not even aware of

In honor of my last semester in college, here are some key takeaways: 

-Learn you. 
-DO IT ALL, this is your only time to do so. 
-Learn how to take care of yourself: mentally and physically 
-Explore a wide variety of topics - the world is not only your subject matter (1/7)
